questions.text: A patient, who was a known case of chronic plaque Psoriasis with more than 50% skin involvement presents to you. Which of the following would you not recommend?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral steroids Oral steroids are not used in the management of chronic plaque psoriasis. Management of psoriasis: <10% BSA affected Topical treatment >10% BSA affected Phototherapy, systemic drugs Topical treatment - it slows overactive epidermis. Topical corticosteroids Vitamin D analogues-e.g.- calcipotriene Coal tar Tazarotene Topical Calcineurin Inhibitors-tacrolimus, Emollients to avoid dryness. Phototherapy Sunlight UV broadband phototherapy - artificial light Photo chemotherapy Plus UVA Eximer laser Pulse dye laser Systemic therapy -e.g. Cyclosporine, methotrexate, acitretin, Apremilast, systemic steroids Biologics TNF-alpha inhibitors Adalimumab Infliximab Etanercept Certolizumab Golimumab IL-23 Agonist Guselkumab IL-12/23 Antagonist Ustekinumab IL-17 Antagonist Secukinumab Ixekizumab IL-17 Receptor Antagonist Brodalumab CD11a Antagonist Efalizumab

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below Image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mycetoma The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mycetoma/ Maduramycosis. It is a localized, chronic, subcutaneous infection Occupation: usually in farmers Earliest stage: firm, painless nodule but with time papules and pustules, which break down to form draining sinuses, appear on the skin surface. Can extend to underlying bones and joints giving rise to periostitis, osteomyelitis, and arthritis, and can produce bony deformity Discharge: Purulent or seropurulent HPE: Actinomycosis shows Sulfur granules : Eosinophilic amorphous material with club-shaped configuration Treatment : Dapsone + Streptomycin/Rifampicin , radical surgery

Highyeild:

Difference: Eumycetoma Actinomycetoma Slowly invasive Rapidly invasive Late presentation Early presentation No pus Pus present Black/brown granules yellowish-white granules Granules 4 to 5 microns in size, in clusters Granules <1 micron, single Gram-negative, GMS PAS positive Gram-positive, GMS PAS negative Responds to itraconazole, amphoB Responds to Sulfonamide, doxycycline

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Sporotrichosis: It is a fungal infection of the skin caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii which present with lesions at the site of scratch that are nodules which appear under the skin along the lymphatic channels Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Cutaneous SCC is an invasive disease which presents as scaly or crusty lumps which may ulcerate. Option D. Rodent ulcer: aka Basal cell carcinoma, is a locally invading skin cancer characterized by slow-growing plaques or nodules.

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the Image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multinucleated Giant cells The given clinical scenario with a cluster of vesicles on erythematous base is suggestive of Genital herpes. Teaneck's finding of herpes shows multinucleated giant cells.

Highyeild:

Herpes virus infection Virus - DNA Virus, multiply within nucleus HSV-1 disease: Above diaphragm Orolabial herpes Herpetic gingivostomatitis Herpetic whitlow Erythema multiforme Eczema herpeticum Mollaret meningitis HSV-2 disease: Below diaphragm Genital herpes with bilateral enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes Primary lesions: Vesicles Multiple grouped tender ulcer Ulcers with polycyclic margins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B . Pund cells: The term is used to describe white blood cells, specifically neutrophils, that have ingested bacterial pathogens. They are not commonly seen in viral infections. Option C . Henderson-Patterson bodies: These are seen in molluscum contagiosum Option D . Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies: These inclusion bodies in the epithelial cells of the conjunctiva are specific for trachoma.

Tzanck test Aka the chickenpox skin test and the herpes skin test. Tzanck smear, is scraping of an ulcer base to look for Tzanck cells. questions.text: The gold standard for allergic contact dermatitis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patch test Gold standard for diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis is the Patch test.

Highyeild:

Patch Test It is undertaken for investigation and confirmation of substances that produce Allergic contact dermatitis. Relies on the principle of type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Method: A series of allergens are applied to the back The allergens on the patch include latex, medications, preservatives, hair dyes, fragrances, resins, and various metals. It needs to stay for 2 to 4 days Positive result: show erythema & papules or vesicles After 48 hours , patch is removed and erythema is noted Another read is taken after 96 hours to check for any delayed reaction. Photopatch test Modification of patch test Done for photo allergen

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A and B. Serum IgE and radioallergosorbent testing (RAST) are typically used to diagnose IgE-mediated allergies, such as those associated with environmental allergens (e.g., pollen, animal dander) or food allergies. Option D . Immuno turbidimetry: It is a laboratory technique used to measure the concentration of certain substances, such as antibodies or antigens, in blood or other fluids.

Extraedge:

Important consideration for patch test Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing Steroids should be stopped before the test (but at doses <15 mg no effect of steroids on the test) Weak positive

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichothiodystrophy The given clinical image showing broken/split hair with alternating light and dark bands called ‘tiger-tail banding ’ is of Trichothiodystrophy.

Highyeild:

Trichothiodystrophy Rare, multisystem, autosomal recessive disorder characterised by sulfur-deficient, short, brittle hair. Affects both males and females equally Cause: Defective DNA repair: Nucleotide excision Features: Low sulphur content on biochemical analysis of hair Trichoschisis (broken or split hairs). Alternating light and dark bands called ' tiger-tail banding' , in the hair shaft, found by polarized light microscopy or trichoscopy. A severely damaged or absent hair cuticle by scanning electron microscopy. Photosensitivity, ichthyosis, intellectual impairment, hematological abnormalities, decreased fertility, and short stature may also be present.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Trichorrhexis invaginata : Aka bamboo hair, occurs due to abnormal keratinization. The hair shaft cortex is structurally weak at specific points along its length. Harder adjacent segments of the hair shaft impact into these softer portions creating a ball and socket appearance. Option B . Trichorrhexis nodosa : the most common abnormality of the hair structure. When a weak hair shaft partially fractures and the cortical cells fragment, uneven spurs form at the fracture point. Option D . Monilethrix: Autosomal dominant inherited disorder in which the affected hair shafts appear beaded a few months after birth. They break off leving patches of the scalp with abnormally short hairs.

questions.text: A child presents to OPD with tense bulla over the trunk. A biopsy of the lesion showed a subepidermal level of blistering and neutrophil infiltration at the tips of dermal papillae. Management of this case involves?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dapsone The given clinical scenario with subepidermal split and papillary tip microabscesses is of Dermatitis herpetiformis. For treatment Gluten-free diet and Dapsone (DOC) is used Dermatitis herpetiformis aka Duhring's disease is a subepidermal immunobullous disease. Target antigen: Epidermal transglutaminase 3 Autoantibody: IgA Associated with Gluten-sensitive enteropathy Characteristics: Intensely pruritic papulovesicular over extensors and buttocks. Histopathology: Subepidermal split Papillary tip microabscess Direct immunofluorescence: Granular or fibrillar pattern Demants herpetforms. Drict inmunofluorescence demoniarating granular igA deposition in the dermal papillae Treatment: Gluten-free diet ( BROW = barley, rye, oats, wheat) DAPSONE

Highyeild:

Subcorneal blisters: Just beneath the stratum corneum Have the thinner roofs. Rupture easily & leave an oozing denuded surface Intra-epidermal blisters: Within the prickle cell layer of the epidermis Have thin roofs Rupture easily & leave an oozing denuded surface Subepidermal blisters: Between the dermis & epidermis Their roofs are relatively thick Tend to be tense May contain blood
